title: Fixed bug in treemap layout where treemap.children() would be ignored.
body: Fixed possible bug in treemap layout where custom treemap.children() function was being ignored. Instead of calling treemap.children(), the 'children' property of each node was being accessed directly.

title: Add extra ring if polygon "surrounds" clip circle.
body:
For example, when using the stereographic projection with a large clip circle of 179°, a polygon surrounding the removed region of 1° radius effectively becomes inverted, such that its vertices define a hole within the large clip circle of 179°. So in this case, we need to insert an additional ring around the clip circle, going in the opposite direction to the inverted polygon, so that the default non-zero winding rule for fill (in both canvas and SVG) fills only the area between the clip edge and the polygon boundary.

The winding number calculation can be optimised using the 3D coordinates directly from the rotation step, rather than performing additional trig. calculations. (Likewise, other clipping operations can also work on 3D coordinates directly.)

Here is North America around the boundary of a stereographic projection:

![](http://www.jasondavies.com/tmp/stereo-clip.png)

title: projection.clipAngle.
body:
Still a few more things I want to do before this is _perfect_:
1. This includes my fix from the clip-complex branch. However, I'd like to try an alternative fix, which should be theoretically more robust (although I haven't managed to break the current fix yet!)
2. Both cutting and circle clipping fail to cope with the clip edge being completely subsumed by a polygon. This is important for the stereographic projection, for example. Should be straightforward to detect, and there are a few tricks to make it efficient as it's fairly rare for this to happen.
3. For non-90° clip angles, I need to detect the case where two endpoints are invisible, but there is an intermediate visible segment.

Optimisation ideas (can be done in a future release, potentially):
1. If we know we're visible, it's safe to start drawing immediately, until we see an intersection. At that point, we need to buffer up the remaining points and do the clever clipping stuff. But the common case is that things are either completely visible or not.
2. Optimise special case of clipAngle(90°): shouldn't need to convert to 3D vectors here.
3. Aside from 90°, the circle clipping uses 3D coordinates, so we can reuse the 3D conversion from the rotation here. (That is, if the rotation even converted to 3D in the first place.)

title: Inherit hue or saturation when interpolating to or from a monochrome color.
body:
Currently if you use `d3.interpolateHsl`or `d3.interpolateHcl` to blend a colour with black, you get red shades introduced. If you do the same with white, you get green shades.

For example, blue + black equals purple:

``` javascript
d3.interpolateHsl("#00f", "#000")(0.5)
//-> "#602060"
```

I would expect to see only shades of blue, from bright to dark.
Tweaking the input slightly gives us the expected result and shows where we're going wrong:

``` javascript
d3.interpolateHsl("#00f", "#001")(0.5)
//-> "#000088"
```

I think the hue value for black and white should be ignored for interpolation. This pull request fixes it for HSL and HCL and adds tests for RGB.

title: Add d3_Color base class.
Automatically interpolate d3.lab instances.
Only attempt to resample if distance < δ.
body:
This improves performance in the case where our input data is already of a high enough resolution, even when subject to distortion.

It’s unlikely that the Douglas–Peucker estimate (perpendicular distance) will be greater than δ if the two input points are already closer than 2δ.

title: Interpolate polygon cuts correctly, and resample.
body: [Example](http://bl.ocks.org/3721735).

title: Add antemeridian cutting for all projections.
body:
Note: this also fixes d3.geo.graticule; I assume it only generates two-point lines in preparation for adaptive resampling. :) However, I think it's conventional to assume the shortest distance given two points on a sphere (otherwise it’s ambiguous), so we should include at least as many points such that the distance is less than 180° between any two points.

I went for the simplest solution and simply inserted points for each crossing point. I can see that it might be nice to only generate 4 points so that there is less overhead when drawing the poles, but this works for now.

title: Add projection.{line,polygon} support to d3.geo.path.
body:
Something along these lines?

I'd be happy to develop this in d3-plugins first if you prefer, e.g. a wrapper to test the concept. I guess I could call it d3.geo.projection.clip, and it would return new GeoJSON feature instead of an SVG path.

title: d3.geo.projection
dsv.parse asynchronous when no arguments
Update chord.js to support negative matrix values
body: The chord layout currently does not support negative values in input matrices; this commit provides support for negative values by making the chord group's angle dependent on the sum of the absolute value of all matrix input values in a group.

title: Small patch to allow the user to specify the center of gravity in the force directed graph
body:
This small update has certainly been useful on our project and thought it might be useful for others as well.  The patch is very small and backwards compatibility is maintained.  I did not update the minimized version.

Hope it helps!

title: Xhr2
body:
The new XHR2 framework looks great.  Here are a few additional ideas:
### xhr.post convenience function

Sending a POST request involves the following steps:
- Specify "POST" as a method in the open()
- Set the Content-Type header correctly 
- Ensure that the supplied data is a string.

Function xhr.post() simplifies the process by re-opening the request, determining  encoding / set header and stringify data if necessary.    Any type-specific methods  (d3.json/d3.text /d3.xml etc) can be switched to a POST by appending .post(data)  to the function call.

For example, the following GET

```
  d3.csv("http://localhost/test?a=1&b=2",fn)
```

can be changed to POST (url-encoded)

```
  d3.csv("http://localhost/test",fn)
    .post("a=1&b=2")
```

or POST (json-encoded)

```
  d3.csv("http://localhost/test",fn)
    .post({a:1,b:2})
```
### Accept Header moved to xhr.open

If mime has been defined at the top level, we use when xhr.open is called (in case it's called twice) as is the case when using type-specific methods  (d3.csv/d3.xml/d3.text etc) with a redefined xhr.open (i.e. xhr.post)
### sendTimeout

By putting a setTimeout(...,0) on the xhr.send and canceling/reinstating upon changes we eliminate the occurance of multiple firings of send  , allowing the send function to be anywhere in the chain, not just at the end.   In node this would be done under process.nextTick().   I realize this is unconventional, but it seems a very effective solution given how javascript sequences execution.
### xhr.open username/password

The XMLHttpRequest allows the specification of username /password.  This option is simply added to xhr.open and passed on.

title: More flexible XHR framework.
body:
This is backwards-compatible, yet adds numerous features to d3.xhr. You can now:
- Use standard node-style callbacks (fixes #473).
- Abort in-flight requests.
- Listen for progress events.
- Listen for load, error and abort events separately.
- Make POST requests (or any other method), including data.
- Set arbitrary request headers.
- Have multiple listeners on requests.

title: Xhr post
body:
Here I have a different approach to the AJAX request.  I delay the execution to next tick, allowing the various parameters to be set by chaining (method, headers and data). 

By default the function is a GET request without any data  (backwards compatible)

title: Reset zoom drift vector for new translate/scale.
body: If a new translate vector or scale is set, the internal drift vector for zooming should be reset appropriately.

title: jamjs integration
body: this simple tweak to the `package.json` should allow the package to work correctly here:  http://jamjs.org/packages/#/details/d3 to work correctly.

title: d3.layout.hierarchical advertised .links() and .nodes() APIs in the documentation, but doesn't have it in the code.
body:
See API docs: https://github.com/mbostock/d3/wiki/Hierarchy-Layout#wiki-nodes

All hierarchical layouts have these, except d3.layout.hierarchy itself. Ran into this when changing some basic .links() code from using d3.layout.tree() to d3.layout.hierarchy() after reading the API docs.

title: method to set the global frame function
Simplify a few arguments.length checks.
force layout: charge and friction are now functors, which allow for prod...
body:
...ucing a per-node friction and/or charge value on every 'tick'; when possible, the charge callback (if one was specified) receives a reference to the constructed quadtree as a third argument: there is no need to have the user construct a costly second quadtree on every tick.

http://bl.ocks.org/3616279 and several other gists of mine can be simplified to using a single force instead of layering two of those on top of one another, when this (and gravity as per-node functor) is done. The interface does not change, thanks to the use of these functors, but the ability of the force layout increases a lot.

The only place where this reduces performance, is in the non-standard case where charge was specifically set to ZERO: now the quadtree is constructed anyhow and the total charge is now calculated (absolute value sum), which is extra work for that situation; anybody else should observe about the same performance.

title: export force.drag instance so user can access it by calling force.drag()...
body:
... with no arguments; the drag events have been namespaced as <event>.force, similar to the other force events: mouseover.force and mouseout.force.

It is very useful for the user to be able to get access to the force layout's drag instance, so we can override/augment the drag behaviour easily (using namespaced events, f.e.); again http://bl.ocks.org/3616279 is one case where such ability is used to add a kind of 'pinning' behaviour for dragged nodes when SHIFT/CTRL has been pressed on mouse release.

The way this 'drag' instance reference is obtained is in line with other D3 functions, where calling it with no arguments returns the drag instance. (The documented use of drag via selection.call() happens to always call it with arguments, so that pans out nicely here :-) )

title: force layout: properly UNSET the .fixed bits: user may be using further ...
body:
...bits and those should be kept intact.

(I use the force layout in several places where it was/is extremely handy to use the higher bits for my own augmentations, which depend on the internal 'if (node.fixed) { dont_move_node }' force.layout logic. 

One such example is http://bl.ocks.org/3616279 which is a layout which adds 'pinning' baheviour where nodes stick to the dragged-to location when you keep SHIFT or CTRL pressed when stopping the drag (when you try that gist, it has the known issue that it doesn't properly keep/release the pinned state; that's an irrelevant detail of that specific example.)

title: Add "*/*" to Accept header.
body:
This avoids a 406 error from servers that don't support a given mime type.

See [discussion](https://groups.google.com/d/topic/d3-js/41pT3nXdEVk/discussion).

title: force cluster example: fixed minor hull error ('hulls' --> 'hullset') + ...
body:
...augmented example, showing distance function based on collected node/group info + click on node to expand/collapse (toggle) instead of harder-to-perform dblclick.

(fix: the force example had two var hulls (one object, one array) in a single function. It works, but is not something you want others to copy.)

Now the force-cluster example shows a graphic identical to http://bl.ocks.org/3071239

title: Multitouch dragging!
Empty default enter() and exit() for all selections (previously undefined)
body: This allows for better consistancy among selection objects, with enter() exit() chains ignored if no new .data() has been defined for the selection.  Should be backwards compatible.
